title: Mixed Hearing Loss with Wegenerâ€™s Granulomatosis
chief_complaint: I am having increased difficulty hearing speech in noise. I also feel very fatigued because I constantly have to turn my head to the left to hear people.

problem_summary.course: Right ear stable since last test (2 years ago); Left ear air conduction thresholds deteriorated slightly above 2,000 Hz.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Fatigue; history of Wegener's granulomatosis with cochlear/middle ear involvement and vasculitis; right tympanic membrane perforation.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing in noise; reliance on the left ear causing physical fatigue from turning head.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Monitor hearing stability and discuss amplification options.

history.present_illness: Patient has a long-standing asymmetric hearing loss. Last evaluation was 2 years ago. She reports symptoms of Wegener's granulomatosis have subsided over the past few years and she is not currently taking medication for it.
history.otologic_history: History of Wegener's granulomatosis involving cochlear and middle ear vasculitis. History of right tympanic membrane perforation.
history.medical_psych_history: Wegener's granulomatosis (subsided). Denies tinnitus or dizziness.
history.patient_goals: Monitor hearing and address difficulty in noise.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Severe sensorineural hearing loss (250-1500 Hz) sloping to profound (2000-8000 Hz) with no measurable response at 4k-8k Hz. Left ear: Slight sloping to mild mixed hearing loss (250-3000 Hz), sloping to moderate at 4000 Hz, and steeply sloping to severe at 6000-8000 Hz.

numeric_results.Right_AC_Thresholds: ~80-90 dB HL (low freqs), No Response (high freqs)
numeric_results.Left_AC_Thresholds: ~25-30 dB HL (low freqs), sloping to ~80+ dB HL
numeric_results.Left_Air_Bone_Gap: Present (approx 20-25 dB gap in low frequencies)

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: No measurable SRT; SAT obtained indicating severe loss. WRS could not be completed (vibrotactile response >100 dB HL). Left ear: SRT consistent with PTA; WRS excellent/normal.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Flat tympanogram with normal ear canal volume (Type B). Left ear: Hypercompliant tympanogram (Type Ad).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a complex, asymmetric hearing loss profile. The right ear exhibits a severe-to-profound sensorineural hearing loss with no usable speech discrimination, while the left ear shows a slight-to-mild mixed hearing loss sloping to severe sensorineural loss in the high frequencies with excellent speech recognition. Immittance testing indicates middle ear pathology bilaterally (stiffness/mass effects or scarring on the right, hypercompliance on the left).
counseling_points: Your hearing in the right ear has remained stable, but the left ear shows slight changes in the high pitches.
Because your right ear has very limited hearing, you are relying heavily on your left ear, which explains your fatigue from constantly turning your head.
We recommend an evaluation for hearing aids or assistive devices (like a CROS system or aid for the left ear) to help with speech in noise and reduce your fatigue.
Please continue to follow up with your otologist regarding the Wegener's granulomatosis and ear health.
It is important to use hearing protection in noisy environments to preserve your remaining hearing in the left ear.
notes_for_actor: Portray fatigue and frustration regarding the effort required to hear.
Demonstrate the behavior of turning your left ear toward the speaker during the consultation.
You are knowledgeable about your medical history (Wegener's) but relieved that the systemic symptoms have subsided.
